Explanation: The systematic study of valid rules of inference, analysis and appraisal of arguments.
The systematic study of meaning in language, formal logic and semiotics.
Theory of collections of mathematical objects.
The study of mathematical symbols and the rules for manipulating these symbols.
The study of properties of geometric objects that are preserved under continuous deformations, such as stretching, twisting, crumpling and bending, but not tearing or gluing.
The branch of mathematics dealing with limits and related theories, such as differentiation, integration, measure, infinite series, and analytic functions
Theory of the addition and multiplication of vector spaces
Branch of mathematics concerned with probability as a rigorous mathematical concept expressed in a set of axioms.
Branch of differential geometry that studies smooth manifolds with a Riemannian metric.
The application of probability theory to statistics.
Branch of differential geometry that studies topological spaces that locally resembles Euclidean space near each point.
A theory of time relational to different inertial frames.
A theory that assumes a single relational time for every place and every reference frame
A set of interrelated concepts and principles applying to all systems.
Euclidean geometry with a physical interpretation. it holds reasonably well for small regions of space.

A geometrical theory gives different physical meanings to
the primitives of the abstract theory D of metric spaces.
Any theory containing the mathematical concept of field (an extended imponderable that cannot be transformed away).
Theory of mathematical probability plus a physical interpretation of its primitives U and P.
A class of theories partially interpreted that describe the evolution of physical systems.
The analysis that exhibits the genera to which a set of magnitudes belong.
The study of geometry using a coordinate system.
All series whose terms represent physical objects shall be uniformly convergent on the given interval.
If A and B are time-dependent properties and A determines B (whether causally or stochastically9, then B at time t is a functional of A at all times t’ prior to and up to t.
The basic laws of physics shall be invariant under transfomations of cooordinates representing changes of inertial (Galilean) frames.
If a and B are place-dependent properties and A determines B (whether causally of stochastically), then B at the place x is a functional of a at all places x’ surrounding x.apagado
Only field regions connectible by a field disturbance (hence separated by a timelike interval) can interact.
The basic laws of physics shall be invariant under Lorentz transfomations of cooordinates representing changes of inertial frames.

The basic law statements of physics should hold in any frame of reference and in any coordinate system. They should be preserved under arbitrary changes in coordinate systems, whether or not the latter mirror different physical reference frames.
Or objectivity. The constitutive equations must be invariant under coordinate transformations.
An independent variable present in one constitutive equation is so present in all.
